root.pub-comments: All population numbers were as of 1980.

root.publications: Jackson, Frederick H. 1983. The internal and external relationships of the Trukic languages of Micronesia, 460.

child.pub-comments: “Although the group appears quite firmly established, it is not clear whether Proto-Ponapeic languages subgroup with Trukic languages, or as a part of the Trukic group” (Jackson 1983:437).
child.geography: spoken on islands that range from Tobi, at about 131 degrees east longitude, across approximately 1600 miles of the Pacific Ocean to Lukunor, at about 154 degrees east longitude, and between three and ten degrees north latitude

child.pub-comments: “Ponapean, Mokilese, Pingelapese, and the language of Ngatikese form a distinct subgroup within nuclear Micronesian (Rehg 1981:7-12)” (Jackson 1983:3-4). “Although the group appears quite firmly established, it is not clear whether Proto-Ponapeic languages subgroup with Trukic languages, or as a part of the Trukic group” (Jackson 1983:437).
child.geography: spoken on the island of Ponape, and the atolls of Mokil and Pingelap

child.publications: Jackson, Frederick H. 1983. The internal and external relationships of the Trukic languages of Micronesia, 460.

child.pub-comments: “The language recorded by Kubary is apparently no longer spoken on Mapia, which is now inhabited by people who speak a language closely related to Indonesia” (Jackson 1983:404). “Despite some problematic forms […], it appears highly probably that Old Mapian was a Trukic languages, as suggested by Goodenough and Sugita (1980)” (Jackson 1983:409).
child.geography: spoken on the island of Mapia, located about 100 miles north of West Irian, and well to the south of islands of Tobi, Merir, Sonsorol, and Pulo Anna
child.tree-val: Micronesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Jackson 1983
child.publications: Jackson, Frederick H. 1983. The internal and external relationships of the Trukic languages of Micronesia, 460.

child.tree-val: Micronesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Jackson 1983
child.publications: Jackson, Frederick H. 1983. The internal and external relationships of the Trukic languages of Micronesia, 460.

child.pub-comments: Population: 50. “The position of Pulo Anna, it is argued, is more problematic, with some evidence suggesting that it subgroups with Ulithian, and still other evidence suggesting a closer relationship between Pulo Anna and the 'Nuclear Trukic' group” (Jackson 1983:126).
child.tree-val: Micronesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Jackson 1983
child.publications: Jackson, Frederick H. 1983. The internal and external relationships of the Trukic languages of Micronesia, 460.

child.pub-comments: “Of all the groups proposed...this is perhaps the most weakly supported” (Jackson 1983:436).

child.pub-comments: “Clearly, on the basis of the phonological data, the best analysis is that Kosraean was the first language to separate from the proto-community” (Jackson 1983:355). Also, Kosraean is the “most divergent of the nuclear Micronesian languages” (Jackson 1983:438).
child.geography: spoken on the island of Kosrae (formerly called Kusaie), at the extreme eastern extent of the Caroline Islands
child.tree-val: Micronesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Jackson 1983
child.publications: Jackson, Frederick H. 1983. The internal and external relationships of the Trukic languages of Micronesia, 460.
